About

This website is developed during my free time, and to help with learning some material for a Web Applications Project class I took. I might also use it to host any other sort of projects in the future. However, it's still mainly a sandbox/toy to play with when I'm bored or have some free time and/or and a flimsy excuse to use my Raspberry Pi.

Everything currently runs off a REV 2 Model B Raspberry Pi, running Arch Linux ARM. The web server software used is nginx, which I chose mainly for it's simplicity and low memory footprint. The dynamic DNS services are provided by Free DNS, since it's free to use and does not require free accounts to renew subscriptions every 30 days unlike certain other dynamic DNS providers.

Goals

My goal is to keep this site fully HTML5 and CSS3 compliant, as defined by the W3's markup validation services. That said, I also want to keep the design of this website simple. There are many neat and flashy effects that CSS3 can do, but being a fan of minimalism, I will do my best to keep this site in line with what I believe to believe to be minimal and aesthetically pleasing.
      As part of keeping everything minimalistic and this site being a learning opportunity, for now I plan to keep it static, using handwritten HTML and CSS. Using a web framework is slightly out of the scope of what I wanted for this website, but not out the question.

The theme of the website is loosely inspired by that of the Arch Linux website, in term of clean design, and simple visual effects. The color scheme is derived from Google's Android Holo theme.

Disclaimers

Since this site is self-hosted on a Raspberry Pi sitting in my living room, I can make no guarantees about uptime or stability, be it system breaking Arch Linux ARM updates, WOW!'s somewhat iffy service, or roommates accidentally unplugging the Raspberry Pi...


My intent is to keep this website HTML5 and CSS3 compliant. All code has been validated with the W3C Markup Validation Service and the W3 CSS Validation Service. CSS(3) vendor prefixes are used where available, with priortity given to Firefox and WebKit compatibility. Full and constant compatibility across all browers is not guaranteed.
DNS services provided by FreeDNS. Powered by nginx. Built using Jekyll.
